title: What Germany’s $41B investment in space could mean for Europe
summary:
Germany will invest 35 billion euros ($41.1 billion) into defense space technologies within the next five years — an unprecedented amount for any European country. The decision, made in response to rising tensions with Russia, has been hailed a “watershed moment” for the German and European space sector, and experts say could spur a new […]
The post What Germany’s $41B investment in space could mean for Europe appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: Germany will invest 35 billion euros ($41.1 billion) into defense space technologies within the next five years. The decision, made in response to rising tensions with Russia, has been hailed a “watershed moment” for the German and European space sector. Experts say could spur a new era in European space cooperation. The European Union, which is not directly linked to ESA, also has its own space budget. The EU’s lengthy procurement cycle and preference for established prime contractors has been criticized by the European space small- and medium-sized enterprises and start-ups. Meyer-Brunswick said that the new German space defense budget will finally allow the newcomers their chance to grow and shine. Tereza Pultarova is a London-based science and technology journalist and video producer. She covers European space developments for SpaceNews.com. detailed_news: Romania’s National Institute for Aerospace Research ‘Elie Carafoli’ (INCAS) has completed qualification testing of the Space Rider Descent and Landing Test Model (DLRM) In December 2021, Thales Alenia Space awarded a contract to the Italian Aerospace Research Centre (CIRA) to conduct a series of drop tests aimed at validating the recovery system.

title: European Space Agency and Korea AeroSpace Administration embark on new cooperation
summary: The European Space Agency and the Korea AeroSpace Administration (KASA) have announced they will work together on peaceful uses of space, starting with space weather monitoring and sharing space communications facilities.

title: How time series data is fueling the final frontier
summary:
When we think of space exploration, we picture towering rockets, satellites orbiting Earth and astronaut footprints on the moon. However, behind these grand achievements lies an unsung hero: time series data. Today, as physical AI (or AI that interacts with and learns from the physical world) plays a growing role in space missions, the ability […]
The post How time series data is fueling the final frontier appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: Time series is a record of how things change over time. In aerospace, that means temperatures, voltages, pressure, positioning and thousands of other readings streaming from sensors every second. Time series powers everything from trajectory tracking and fuel monitoring to successful docking operations. Earth observation, deep-space navigation and even unlocking discoveries on Mars all depend on physical AI that’s making decisions. Every major leap in space exploration relies on time series data. Time series has long been the quiet workhorse of aerospace. Now, with the rise of physical AI, it’s moving to the forefront. The future of space exploration depends on how well we harness it. title: Maxar retires its name, rebrands as Vantor and Lanteris
summary:
The Maxar name is disappearing from the space industry as two successor companies emerge with distinct identities: Maxar Intelligence will now operate as Vantor, and Maxar Space Systems will go by Lanteris
The post Maxar retires its name, rebrands as Vantor and Lanteris appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: Maxar’s satellite manufacturing arm was hit hard by a global slump in commercial GEO communications satellites. Order volumes fell as operators faced excess capacity, shifting customer demands and the rise of low Earth orbit (LEO) constellations. The company shifted its focus toward government work and smaller satellites.

title: Advancing Europe’s quantum secure communications from space
summary: The European Space Agency (ESA) has signed a €50 million contract with aerospace company Thales Alenia Space to begin the preliminary design phase of the Security And cryptoGrAphic (SAGA) mission. This agreement enables SAGA to continue to its preliminary design review, marking a relevant step towards establishing secure, space-based communications using quantum technologies.
detailed_news: ESA has signed a €50 million contract with aerospace company Thales Alenia Space to begin the preliminary design phase of the Security And cryptoGrAphic (SAGA) mission. SAGA, developed by ESA, aims to demonstrate quantum key distribution (QKD) via satellites.

title: Sea-level monitoring satellite unboxed
summary: Following its arrival in California a few weeks ago, the time has come for spacecraft engineers to ready the next sea-level monitoring satellite, Copernicus Sentinel-6B, for launch, which is slated for November.
detailed_news: The Copernicus Sentinel-6B satellite is set to launch in November. It will carry forward the legacy of the first satellite, launched in November 2020. The satellite will undergo various functional tests, solar array checks and will be fuelled for its life in orbit. The exact launch date is to be announced in the coming weeks.

All ESA Member States – and Canada as the only Cooperating State – will make their commitments for the coming three years during the ESA Ministerial Council in Bremen.

But that constellation was scrapped just over a month later on Sept. 8 after EchoStar sold spectrum underpinning […]

title: Cassini proves complex chemistry in Enceladus ocean
summary: Scientists digging through data collected by the Cassini spacecraft have found new complex organic molecules spewing from Saturn’s moon Enceladus. This is a clear sign that complex chemical reactions are taking place within its underground ocean. Some of these reactions could be part of chains that lead to even more complex, potentially biologically relevant molecules.
detailed_news: Scientists have found new complex organic molecules spewing from Saturn’s moon Enceladus. This is a clear sign that complex chemical reactions are taking place within its underground ocean. Some of these reactions could be part of chains that lead to even more complex, potentially biologically relevant molecules. This discovery further strengthens the case for a dedicated European Space Agency (ESA) mission to orbit and land on the moon. Discoveries from Cassini are valuable for planning a future ESA mission dedicated to Enceladus. The plan is to fly through the jets and even land on the moon's south polar terrain to collect samples. A mission that takes measurements directly from the moon’s surface, seeking out signs of life, would offer Europe a front seat in Solar System science.

title: International Space Station: Launching NASA and Humanity into Deep Space
summary: Curiosity and the desire to explore are traits deeply rooted in human nature. Space exploration is no exception; it reflects humanity’s timeless drive to seek new horizons, challenge our limits, and understand our universe. The advancements of modern civilization—from the electricity that powers our homes to basic hygienic breakthroughs that ensure our health— happened thanks […]
detailed_news: In November 2025, NASA and its international partners will surpass 25 years of continuous human presence aboard the International Space Station. As NASA prepares for Artemis missions to the Moon and sets sights on Mars, the space station continues to enable groundbreaking research not possible on Earth. The space station provides a testbed to refine these systems before human’s travel to distant destinations. Astronauts aboard the space station have collected photographs to document Earth’s surface through Crew Earth Observations. Now, those same techniques are being adapted for Artemis II , where astronauts will use handheld cameras to capture images of the Moon. Researchers have also advanced 3D printing in space , enabling astronauts to make tools and parts on-demand. Measurements taken on Artemis II crew will expand a repository of human health data. NASA researchers hope to use this data repository to develop protocols aimed at keeping astronauts healthy on missions to the Moon, Mars, and beyond. Organ-chip research could improve crew prevention measures and create personalized medical treatments for humans, on Earth and in space.

title: Making High Fidelity Fluxgate Cores for Space Science and Space Weather Missions
summary: A NASA-sponsored team at the University of Iowa (UI) is restoring and advancing the nation’s capability to make high-fidelity magnetic field measurements needed to investigate space weather that can impact our communication and power grids on Earth and our assets in space.
detailed_news: NASA-sponsored team at the University of Iowa is restoring and advancing the nation's capability to make high-fidelity magnetic field measurements. Fluxgate magnetometers are widely-used space science and space weather instruments. The ferromagnetic cores are produced starting from base metal powders that are melted into custom alloys, rolled into thin foils. The SWIM sensor can also be manufactured with a lightweight carbon-composite cover (or the cover can be omitted) to achieve a sensor mass of ~110 g. Using three smaller cores with improved metallurgy instead of six large racetrack cores reduced the power consumption by a factor of two. The MAGIC electronics use a traditional analog demodulator fluxgate and magnetic feedback design.

title: ViaSat-3 F2 delivered to Florida for October launch
summary:
TAMPA, Fla. — Viasat’s second ViaSat-3 satellite has arrived in Florida for a launch in the second half of October, giving the company another chance to operate a terabit-per-second broadband powerhouse from geostationary orbit.
The post ViaSat-3 F2 delivered to Florida for October launch appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: Viasat’s second ViaSat-3 satellite has arrived in Florida for a launch in the second half of October. Boeing said Sept. 30 that the six-ton satellite was delivered from its factory in California. The satellite will be integrated with a United Launch Alliance Atlas 5 rocket.

title: SpaceX intensifies testing to ready Pad 2 at Starbase

authors.name: Alejandro Alcantarilla Romera and Chris Bergin

summary:
SpaceX is ramping up testing of its second launch pad at Starbase, conducting multiple checkouts…
The post SpaceX intensifies testing to ready Pad 2 at Starbase appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: SpaceX is ramping up testing of its second launch pad at Starbase, conducting multiple checkouts of the water deluge system. The flurry of activity highlights the company’s push toward operational readiness for Pad 2, including enhancements to water management and structural protections. The pad is set to host its first launch during Flight 12 of Starship in 2026. Pad 2 at Starbase is ramping up its testing ahead of hosting the next version of Starship, starting with Flight 12 next year. A key advantage over Pad 1 is the potential for same-day retests following an abort. Pad 2’s setup allows for quicker recovery and retry once the issue is resolved. The “Megabunker’ has emerged at the old launch site entrance. It resembles a fortified medieval fortress, sparking speculation about its purpose. Experts suggest it may house critical electronics and control equipment for pad operations. The next step involves fitting flex hoses to link the quick disconnects to ground systems.

Estonia marked its first 10 years as an ESA Member State. Exoplanet-tracking Plato spacecraft arrived at ESTEC Test Centre in the Netherlands for testing.

title: Gaia discovers our galaxy’s great wave
summary: Our Milky Way galaxy never sits still: it rotates and wobbles. And now, data from the European Space Agency’s Gaia space telescope reveal that our galaxy also has a giant wave rippling outwards from its centre.
detailed_news: Since the 1950s, we've known that the Milky Way's disc is warped. Then in 2020 Gaia discovered that this disc wobbles over time. And now it has become clear that a great wave stirs the motion of stars in our galaxy over distances of tens of thousands of light-years from the Sun. ‘This observed behaviour is consistent with what we would expect from a wave,’ says Eloisa Poggio from INAF in Italy. Young giant stars and Cepheids move with the wave. It is possible that young stars retain the memory of the wave information from the gas itself, from which they were born. Scientists do not know the origin of these galactic shakes. A past collision with a dwarf galaxy could be a possible explanation.

The Canadian Space Agency will spend $5 million on projects that expand the use of satellite imagery and data.

title: Firefly Alpha booster destroyed in ground test
summary:
The booster that was to launch the return-to-flight mission of Firefly Aerospace’s Alpha rocket was destroyed in testing Sept. 29, dealing another setback to the vehicle program.
The post Firefly Alpha booster destroyed in ground test appeared first on SpaceNews.

Third-party video showed an explosion on the test stand followed by a second explosion. Firefly had planned the launch for some time in the fourth quarter but had not disclosed a date.
